metadata.description: Scenario-Based Study Companion for AZ-104 certification - validates practical skills for implementing, managing, and monitoring core Azure services.

question.title: RBAC Scope Selection
question.scenario: You must allow a support team to restart VMs and read VM metrics, but only in the Prod-App1 resource group. They must not manage networking or IAM anywhere else.
question.question-text: Where and how should you assign permissions?

choices.choice: Assign the Global Administrator role at the tenant level
Assign an Azure RBAC role at the Prod-App1 resource group scope
Assign the Contributor role at the subscription level
Create a custom role with permissions on all resource groups

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Assign an Azure RBAC role at the resource group scope to limit the blast radius to only that resource group.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Assign permissions at the resource group scope (not subscription) to constrain blast radius. Use a built-in role that covers VM operations (e.g., VM Contributor) plus monitoring-read access if needed. Prefer assigning the role to an Entra ID group, not individual users.

ul.li: Scope inheritance means subscription-level assignments leak privileges to all RGs; avoid it unless required.
"Contributor" is often too broad; choose the narrowest built-in role(s).
If they need metrics/logs, ensure they also have access to the target Log Analytics workspace (workspace permissions are separate from resource permissions).

question.title: Management Groups vs Subscriptions
question.scenario: Your org has 12 subscriptions (prod/non-prod across business units). You need a single place to apply baseline policies (tag requirements, region restrictions) and standard RBAC.
question.question-text: What Azure construct should you use?

choices.choice: A single subscription with multiple resource groups

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Management groups.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use management groups to organize subscriptions and apply Azure Policy and RBAC at a higher scope so they inherit. Build a hierarchy like Root -> Platform -> (Prod, NonProd) -> BU.

ul.li: Policies assigned at a management group inherit to child subscriptions unless excluded.
Use initiatives for baseline policy sets (landing zone style).
Watch out for "exception sprawl": manage exemptions intentionally and track them.

question.title: Policy: Enforce Tags
question.scenario: Finance requires every resource to have tags: CostCenter, Owner, Env. Noncompliant deployments must fail in prod, but only be reported in dev.

choices.choice: Azure Policy with deny effect in prod and audit effect in dev
RBAC roles that prevent resource creation without tags
Resource locks on all resources without tags
Azure Blueprints with automatic tag assignment

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Azure Policy with deny in prod and audit in dev.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Create a policy/initiative requiring tags; assign deny to the prod management group/subscriptions and audit to dev. Use separate assignments for prod vs dev.

ul.li: "Append/modify" effects vary by resource type; don't assume auto-tagging works everywhere (verify per resource).
Policy failures surface as deployment failures; administrators must recognize policy as the root cause.
Use policy exemptions sparingly with documented rationale.

question.title: RBAC vs Azure Policy (Common Confusion)
question.scenario: A team wants to "prevent users from creating public IPs." Another team wants to "prevent users from deleting VNets."

choices.choice: Use Azure Policy for both requirements
Use Azure Policy for preventing public IP creation; use RBAC for restricting VNet deletion
Use resource locks for both requirements

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Use Azure Policy for preventing resource creation patterns; use RBAC for restricting delete actions.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Azure Policy is best for enforcing configuration/allowed SKUs/regions ("no public IP resource"). RBAC controls actions like delete; deny deletion by not granting delete permissions (and/or use resource locks for safety).

ul.li: Policy blocks creation even if RBAC would allow it.
Resource locks help prevent accidental deletion but are not a governance substitute for RBAC.
Don't misuse policy for permissioning; don't misuse RBAC for configuration compliance.

question.title: Break-Glass Access Design
question.scenario: You need an emergency access path if Entra Conditional Access is misconfigured and admins are locked out.
question.question-text: What is the standard Azure approach?

choices.choice: Create break-glass accounts excluded from Conditional Access policies
Use Azure Support to reset admin passwords
Store admin credentials in a shared document

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Create break-glass accounts and protect them appropriately.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Maintain one or two break-glass Entra accounts with strong credentials stored securely, excluded from risky Conditional Access policies, and monitored with alerts.

ul.li: Break-glass accounts should be rarely used and heavily monitored (sign-in alerts).
Avoid assigning broad roles permanently; consider just-in-time/PIM if in scope (verify exam coverage).
Ensure recovery procedures are documented and tested.

question.title: Storage: Keys vs SAS vs Entra ID
question.scenario: A vendor needs upload access to a single blob container for 24 hours. You must be able to revoke access.

choices.choice: Share the storage account access keys with the vendor
Create a SAS token with a stored access policy
Add the vendor as a Contributor on the storage account
Create a new storage account for the vendor

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: SAS (preferably governed with a stored access policy).

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use a SAS scoped to the container with write-only permissions and short expiry; use a stored access policy (if suitable) to allow revocation without rotating account keys. Avoid sharing storage account keys.

ul.li: Storage account keys grant full control; treat as high-risk secrets.
SAS is time-bound and can be permission-scoped; still treat as a credential.
If using Private Endpoint, ensure the vendor can reach it (or use public endpoint with network restrictions).

question.title: Storage Networking: Public Endpoint Lockdown
question.scenario: A storage account must be accessible only from a specific VNet. No public internet access is allowed.

choices.choice: Private Endpoint with private DNS and disable public network access
Storage firewall rules allowing all Azure services
Enable anonymous blob access with IP restrictions

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Private Endpoint + disable public network access (or restrict via firewall rules), plus DNS.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use Private Endpoint for the storage account (Blob, File, etc.) and restrict/disable public network access. Configure Private DNS so clients resolve the storage FQDN to the private IP.

ul.li: DNS is the trap: if name resolution still returns the public endpoint, traffic won't be private.
Network rules alone don't make it private; Private Endpoint changes routing.
Verify service-specific settings for "public network access" toggles and required DNS zones.

question.title: Storage Replication Choice
question.scenario: A workload needs higher availability within a region, but compliance prohibits data leaving the region.
question.question-text: What replication option is usually appropriate?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Zone-redundant storage (ZRS), region-dependent.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Choose ZRS for intra-region zone redundancy (if supported in that region/account kind). Avoid GRS/GZRS because they replicate to a paired region (data leaves region boundary).

ul.li: Replication support varies by region and account type - verify availability.
Understand tradeoffs: cost vs durability/availability vs read-access patterns.
For DR requirements across regions, compliance constraints must explicitly allow it.

question.title: Blob Lifecycle Management
question.scenario: You store logs in Blob. After 30 days, they should move to cooler storage; after 180 days, delete.

choices.choice: Azure Logic Apps with scheduled triggers

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Blob lifecycle management rules.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Configure lifecycle management on the storage account/container to tier blobs after 30 days and delete after 180 days.

ul.li: Ensure rules match blob types (block/page/append) and prefixes/tags.
Tiering behavior and costs differ by access tier; verify if rehydration latency matters.
If using immutability/legal hold, lifecycle deletion may be blocked.

question.title: Azure Files Identity Access
question.scenario: A Windows fleet must mount a file share using identity-based auth (no keys embedded).

choices.choice: Azure Files with identity integration (Entra ID / AD DS-based)
Store storage account keys in each VM's registry
Use Azure Blob storage instead of Files
Create individual SAS tokens for each VM

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Azure Files with identity integration (Entra ID / AD DS-based), depending on environment.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use Azure Files with an identity-based model (options depend on your directory integration). Configure the appropriate identity provider and assign permissions so clients authenticate without storage keys.

ul.li: The exact identity integration path depends on whether you use Entra Kerberos / AD DS / AAD DS; verify current supported modes.
NTFS ACLs and share-level permissions can both apply; understand where enforcement occurs.
Network path (private endpoint vs public) affects client connectivity.

question.title: VM Availability Decision
question.scenario: A business-critical VM must remain available during planned maintenance and reduce single-datacenter risk.
question.question-text: What deployment pattern should you choose?

choices.choice: Deploy the VM without any availability configuration
Deploy multiple VMs in the same fault domain

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Use Availability Zones (if region supports); otherwise use Availability Set.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Prefer Availability Zones for higher resilience across datacenters. If zones aren't available, use an Availability Set for fault/update domain separation.

ul.li: Zone support is regional; verify per region.
Availability Sets reduce rack-level correlated failure but not datacenter-level outages.
For multi-VM apps, place dependencies (LB, disks, IPs) in compatible zone patterns.

question.title: VM Sizing Under Constraints
question.scenario: A VM hits CPU saturation at peak. Budget allows minimal spend increase.
question.question-text: What are the two primary scaling options, and what's the usual "first move"?

choices.choice: Scale up (bigger size) for a single VM is usually quickest
Always scale out with more instances first
Migrate to a different Azure region

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Scale up (bigger size) or scale out (more instances). First move often scale up for a single VM.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: For a single VM app, scale up (resize SKU) is usually quickest. For horizontally scalable apps, scale out using multiple instances behind a load balancer (often VMSS).

ul.li: Scale up can require reboot/downtime depending on SKU change constraints (verify).
Scale out requires statelessness or externalized state.
Watch quotas/region capacity constraints.

question.title: VMSS vs Multiple Standalone VMs
question.scenario: You need 20 identical web servers with autoscaling and uniform configuration.
question.question-text: Should you deploy individual VMs or a VM Scale Set?

choices.choice: Deploy 20 individual VMs with manual configuration

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: VM Scale Set.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use VMSS to manage a fleet: uniform config, autoscale rules, health-based instance repair, and easier rolling upgrades.

ul.li: VMSS is best for stateless tiers; stateful workloads complicate scaling.
Rolling upgrades and instance reimage patterns differ from standalone VMs; understand operational model.
Verify any per-orchestration-mode limits/behaviors.

question.title: VM Disk Choice: Performance Issue
question.scenario: A VM shows high disk latency and queue depth. You suspect the disk tier is too low.
question.question-text: What Azure changes are typically relevant?

choices.choice: Upgrade disk tier/SKU, consider striping, and confirm caching settings
Add more NICs to the VM

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Upgrade disk tier/SKU, consider striping, and confirm caching settings.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Evaluate managed disk performance tier (e.g., Standard vs Premium), ensure the VM size supports required IOPS/throughput, and review disk caching configuration where applicable. Consider multiple data disks with striping if needed.

ul.li: VM size caps storage throughput; changing disk alone may not fix it.
OS disk vs data disk patterns differ; don't put heavy data on OS disk by accident.
Exact IOPS/throughput numbers are SKU-specific - verify in official docs.

question.title: VM Extension for Configuration
question.scenario: You must run a one-time bootstrap script on 100 VMs after deployment.

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Custom Script Extension.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use the Custom Script Extension (or equivalent automation mechanism) to execute scripts post-deployment at scale; in VMSS, apply extension as part of the model.

ul.li: Handle idempotency: extension retries can rerun scripts.
Store scripts securely (e.g., storage with SAS, or repo) and restrict access.
Verify extension timeout/retry behavior in official docs.

question.title: VM Backup Requirement
question.scenario: You must backup VMs nightly and retain 30 days.
question.question-text: What service do you use and where do you configure policy?

choices.choice: Azure Backup with a Recovery Services vault and backup policy
Manual VM snapshots using Azure CLI
Export VMs to Azure Blob storage

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Azure Backup with a Recovery Services vault; set a backup policy.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use Azure Backup via a Recovery Services vault, create a backup policy for nightly backups and 30-day retention, and enable protection on target VMs.

ul.li: Understand soft delete and deletion protection behaviors (operational recovery implications).
Verify retention granularity and supported schedules per workload type.
RBAC to vault and backup operations is separate from VM permissions.

question.title: Network Segmentation with Subnets
question.scenario: You have a VNet with web, app, data tiers. You need to restrict web -> data directly but allow web -> app -> data.

choices.choice: Use a single NSG for all subnets
NSGs applied to subnets with explicit allow/deny rules for required flows

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: NSGs applied to subnets (and/or NICs), allowing required flows only.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Apply NSGs to the web, app, and data subnets with explicit allow rules for required ports between tiers and denies for disallowed direct traffic.

ul.li: NSGs are evaluated by priority; "first match wins."
Default rules allow VNet traffic unless overridden; you must add explicit denies/controls.
Use Application Security Groups (ASGs) to avoid IP-based rule sprawl (verify exam depth).

question.title: NSG Troubleshooting
question.scenario: A VM cannot be reached on TCP/443 from the internet. Public IP exists.

choices.choice: NSG inbound rules, effective security rules, NIC/subnet association, then route and OS firewall
Delete and recreate the public IP

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: NSG inbound rules, effective security rules, NIC/subnet association, then route and OS firewall.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Check effective NSG rules (subnet + NIC), confirm inbound 443 is allowed, verify no higher-priority deny, confirm VM is listening and OS firewall allows 443, and ensure routing/NAT is correct.

ul.li: Many failures are "shadowed" rules (broad deny with higher priority).
Subnet NSG and NIC NSG both apply; most restrictive outcome wins.
Don't forget app-level listener configuration and health probes if behind a load balancer.

question.title: UDR Forced Tunneling
question.scenario: Security requires all outbound internet traffic from a subnet to go through a network appliance.

choices.choice: User-defined routes (UDR) with NVA as next hop
Enable IP forwarding on VMs only

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: User-defined routes (UDR) to an NVA as next hop.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Create a route table with a default route (0.0.0.0/0) pointing to the virtual appliance next hop, associate it with the subnet, and ensure the NVA can forward traffic.

ul.li: Asymmetric routing can break flows; ensure return path matches.
Verify NVA IP forwarding settings and any required SNAT/NAT configuration.
Confirm no conflicting routes (system vs UDR) override expected behavior.

question.title: VNet Peering Use Case
question.scenario: Two VNets in the same region must communicate privately with low latency. No encryption requirement.

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: VNet peering.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use VNet peering for private connectivity over the Microsoft backbone with minimal latency and no gateway overhead.

ul.li: Don't assume transitive routing across multiple peerings; design explicitly.
For hub/spoke, evaluate gateway transit and "use remote gateway" settings (verify details).
Verify peering limits and address space overlap constraints.

question.title: Hub/Spoke DNS Trap
question.scenario: You deploy Private Endpoints in a spoke VNet but name resolution from workloads still returns public IPs.

choices.choice: The Private Endpoint was not created correctly
Private DNS zone linkage/forwarding is missing
The spoke VNet needs more subnets
Public IP addresses need to be removed

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Private DNS zone linkage/forwarding.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: You likely need Private DNS zones linked to the spoke VNets (or DNS forwarding from hub) so the service FQDN resolves to the private endpoint address.

ul.li: Private Endpoint without correct DNS often behaves "public" from the client perspective.
Central DNS in hub requires conditional forwarders or resolver patterns (verify).
Validate with nslookup/resolver checks from the workload subnet.

question.title: Load Balancer vs Application Gateway
question.scenario: You need TLS termination, path-based routing, and WAF for multiple web apps.

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Application Gateway (WAF).

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Choose Application Gateway with WAF for L7 HTTP/S routing, TLS termination, and security features.

ul.li: Azure Load Balancer is L4 and won't do URL routing or WAF.
Health probe differences can cause "all backends down" surprises.
Verify SKU/feature support (v2 vs older) in official docs.

question.title: NAT for Outbound Stability
question.scenario: A web app hosted on VMs must call an external API that whitelists your source IP. Current outbound IP changes unpredictably when scaling.

choices.choice: Assign public IPs to each VM

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: NAT Gateway (or a controlled egress pattern).

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use a NAT Gateway on the subnet (or another controlled egress design) to provide stable outbound IPs for the VMs, especially when scaling.

ul.li: Stable outbound requires controlling the SNAT path; don't assume public IP on VM equals outbound IP.
Ensure route tables don't divert traffic around your NAT path.
Verify any SNAT port exhaustion patterns for high connection rates.

question.title: VPN Gateway vs ExpressRoute (Conceptual)
question.scenario: You need private connectivity from on-prem to Azure with predictable performance and higher throughput requirements.

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: ExpressRoute.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use ExpressRoute for private, dedicated connectivity; use VPN Gateway when internet-based encrypted tunnels are sufficient and quicker/cheaper.

ul.li: ExpressRoute introduces provider/circuit operational dependencies.
VPN is easier but performance varies with internet conditions.
Verify SKU constraints and routing (BGP) requirements.

question.title: Monitoring: Metrics vs Logs
question.scenario: You need near-real-time alerting when VM CPU > 90% for 10 minutes.
question.question-text: Should you use logs or metrics?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Metrics alert.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use an Azure Monitor metric alert for CPU; metrics are purpose-built for threshold alerting with low latency.

ul.li: Logs are better for deep diagnostics and query-based detections.
Ensure correct aggregation (avg/max) and evaluation window.
Verify minimum metric granularity for the resource type.

question.title: Monitoring: Centralized Troubleshooting
question.scenario: A production incident requires correlating NSG flow failures, VM events, and platform incidents.
question.question-text: What Azure services/features should be in place?

choices.choice: Azure Monitor + Log Analytics + diagnostic settings + Service Health

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Azure Monitor + Log Analytics + diagnostic settings + Service Health.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Route logs via diagnostic settings to Log Analytics, use Azure Monitor for alerts and dashboards, and check Service Health/Resource Health during incidents.

ul.li: Without diagnostic settings, many resource logs won't be collected.
Separate platform incidents from resource misconfiguration quickly.
Retention and cost controls depend on table plans - verify in official docs.

question.title: Alert Noise Control
question.scenario: Your alert triggers every minute and spams on-call during sustained high CPU.
question.question-text: What change reduces noise while staying responsive?

choices.choice: Use stateful alerting and adjust frequency/suppression

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Use stateful alerting / adjust frequency and suppression.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Configure the alert to be stateful (fires once until resolved), and tune evaluation frequency and window to match the signal.

ul.li: Alert tuning is as important as the threshold; poorly tuned alerts create operational failure.
Use action groups with appropriate routing (email/SMS/webhook) and escalation.
Verify alert rule type-specific behavior (metric vs log vs activity).

question.title: Activity Log Alerting (Control-Plane Changes)
question.scenario: Security wants alerts when someone creates role assignments or modifies NSGs.

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Activity Log alerts.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use Activity Log-based alerts for control-plane operations (role assignment changes, resource write/delete actions).

ul.li: Activity Log is subscription-scoped; ensure coverage across subscriptions.
For deeper change context, route Activity Log to Log Analytics for queries.
Don't confuse with data-plane logs (different sources).

question.title: Resource Locks
question.scenario: A team keeps accidentally deleting a critical VNet. You need a quick safety mechanism without redesigning IAM immediately.

choices.choice: Move the VNet to a different subscription

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Resource lock (CanNotDelete).

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Apply a CanNotDelete lock to the VNet (or RG) to prevent deletion unless the lock is removed by someone authorized.

ul.li: Locks are not a replacement for RBAC; they're a guardrail.
Locks can block automation/deployments that expect delete/replace operations.
Ensure only a small set of admins can remove locks.

question.title: Cost Management Guardrails
question.scenario: A subscription's spend is spiking unexpectedly. You need an automated notification at 80% of monthly budget and hard stop is not allowed.

choices.choice: Azure Policy to block all deployments

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Budgets with alerts.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use Azure Budgets to set thresholds (e.g., 80%) and notify via action groups/email; also use cost analysis to identify drivers.

ul.li: Budgets alert; they typically don't stop resource creation by themselves (use policy for enforcement).
Tag governance enables cost attribution; enforce tags.
Consider anomaly detection features if available (verify).

question.title: Tag Strategy for Chargeback
question.scenario: Finance needs chargeback per department and environment.

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Tagging + policy enforcement + cost reporting.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Implement a standard tag schema (Dept, Env, App, Owner, CostCenter), enforce with Azure Policy, and use Cost Management views grouped by tags.

ul.li: Missing tags break chargeback reports; enforce early at landing zone stage.
Some resources may not support tag inheritance the way you expect - verify.
Use management group hierarchy to align reporting boundaries.

question.title: Subscription Design
question.scenario: You must separate dev/test from prod to reduce blast radius and meet compliance.
question.question-text: What's the usual Azure design decision?

choices.choice: Use a single subscription with resource groups
Separate subscriptions for prod and non-prod

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Separate subscriptions.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use separate subscriptions for prod and non-prod (and possibly separate by business unit) so RBAC, policy, budgets, and quotas isolate environments.

ul.li: Subscriptions are strong boundaries for access and billing; RGs are lifecycle boundaries.
Policy inheritance via management groups keeps controls consistent.
Quotas and provider registrations can differ per subscription - plan accordingly.

question.title: Diagnosing "Deployment Failed"
question.scenario: An ARM deployment fails with a generic authorization error. The principal has Contributor on the RG.

choices.choice: Policy deny or missing permissions on dependent resources

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Policy deny or missing permissions on dependent resources (e.g., network, workspace).

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Check whether Azure Policy denied the operation or whether the deployment needs permissions on a different scope/resource (e.g., subnet in shared VNet, Log Analytics workspace, key vault).

ul.li: Many deployments touch resources outside the target RG (shared network, managed identities).
Policy denies present as deployment failures; review policy compliance and activity logs.
Least privilege assignments can require multiple targeted role grants across scopes.

question.title: Key Vault Integration for Secrets
question.scenario: Apps running on VMs need to retrieve secrets without storing credentials on disk.

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Managed identity + Key Vault access.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Enable a managed identity on the VM/VMSS and grant it appropriate Key Vault access (RBAC or access policies depending on configuration) so the app can fetch secrets without embedded credentials.

ul.li: "Identity exists" doesn't mean "has permission"; you must grant Key Vault authorization.
Network restrictions on Key Vault can block access; ensure private endpoint/DNS if locked down.
Verify whether the exam expects RBAC vs access policy model for Key Vault in your version.

question.title: Storage + Key Vault Pattern
question.scenario: You must eliminate storage account keys from application configuration while still accessing blobs.

choices.choice: Share storage account keys via email
Use Entra ID-based access (RBAC) instead of shared key
Create SAS tokens with no expiry

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Use Entra ID-based access (RBAC) instead of shared key.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use Entra ID authentication for Blob access with appropriate RBAC roles; avoid shared key entirely. If any secrets remain (e.g., SAS), store them in Key Vault.

ul.li: Entra ID access requires correct role assignment at the storage scope and compatible SDK/auth flows.
SAS is still a credential; prefer identity-based access when possible.
Verify the exact role needed (Blob Data Contributor/Reader, etc.).

question.title: VM Patch Management Concept
question.scenario: You need a consistent patching approach across many VMs with reporting.
question.question-text: What Azure-native option is commonly used?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Azure Update Management / Update Manager (verify current product naming).

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use Azure's VM update/patch management capability (often integrated with Azure Monitor/automation) to schedule patches and report compliance.

ul.li: Product names and feature sets evolve; verify the current "official" service and workflow.
Patching differs for Windows vs Linux; confirm prerequisites (agents/extensions).
Coordinate with maintenance windows and app availability requirements.

question.title: Storage Immutability Requirement
question.scenario: Legal requires retention of certain blobs for 7 years with WORM semantics.

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Immutable blob storage policy.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Configure immutability (time-based retention and/or legal hold) on the container to enforce WORM retention.

ul.li: Immutability can block deletions and lifecycle rules.
Ensure operational processes understand "cannot delete" behavior.
Verify exact retention limits and lock states in official docs.

question.title: Restore vs Recreate (Disaster Recovery Thinking)
question.scenario: A VM is corrupted after a bad change. You have backups.
question.question-text: What's the fastest likely recovery path?

choices.choice: Restore from backup (or restore disks) and redeploy
Wait for the VM to self-heal

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Restore from backup (or restore disks) and redeploy.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use Azure Backup to restore the VM (or restore disks) to a known good point-in-time, then validate network and dependencies.

ul.li: Restore method choice depends on whether you need the whole VM or just data disks.
Ensure you can restore into a quarantine network if security incident suspected.
Verify recovery time depends on size, region, and storage performance.

question.title: Diagnose Storage Access Denied
question.scenario: An app gets "403 Forbidden" accessing a blob. It uses Entra ID auth.
question.question-text: What are the top likely causes?

choices.choice: Missing RBAC role, wrong scope, or token/audience mismatch

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Missing RBAC role, wrong scope, or token/audience mismatch.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Confirm the principal has the correct Blob Data role at the right scope (container/account), confirm the app is requesting tokens for the correct resource audience, and confirm no network restriction blocks access.

ul.li: Control-plane roles (Contributor) do not grant data-plane access; you need data roles.
Private endpoint without DNS can cause unexpected pathing failures.
If using SAS, validate expiry/permissions; if using keys, ensure correct key and rotation.

question.title: "I Can Ping But Not Connect"
question.scenario: Two VMs in same VNet can ping but cannot connect on TCP/1433.
question.question-text: What's the most likely Azure control?

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: NSG rules.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: ICMP ping success doesn't prove TCP is allowed. Check NSG inbound/outbound rules for the subnets/NICs, and confirm OS firewall allows 1433.

ul.li: NSGs are L3/L4; protocol/port matters.
Effective security rules view is faster than reading multiple NSGs manually.
UDR/NVA can also affect flows; check effective routes if NSGs look correct.

question.title: Private Endpoint vs Service Endpoint
question.scenario: You need private connectivity to a PaaS service and want the service to have a private IP in your VNet.

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Private Endpoint.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Choose Private Endpoint if you need a private IP in your VNet for the service. Service endpoints keep traffic on Microsoft backbone but do not give the service a private IP in your VNet.

ul.li: Private Endpoint requires DNS alignment; service endpoints have different DNS implications.
Network security posture differs; ensure you meet "no public endpoint" requirements.
Verify service endpoint support by service type.

question.title: Log Analytics Workspace Access
question.scenario: A user can view VM resources but cannot query logs in Log Analytics.
question.question-text: Why, and what do you change?

choices.choice: Workspace permissions are separate; grant workspace access
The user needs Global Administrator role

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Workspace permissions are separate; grant workspace access.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Grant the user appropriate permissions on the Log Analytics workspace (RBAC roles for Log Analytics) in addition to resource permissions.

ul.li: Resource-level RBAC doesn't automatically grant workspace query permission.
Central workspaces often live in shared subscriptions; scope matters.
Ensure least privilege: reader vs contributor vs analytics-specific roles (verify).

question.title: Diagnostic Settings Coverage Gap
question.scenario: You have a Log Analytics workspace but see no NSG flow logs or storage logs.

choices.choice: Diagnostic settings not enabled on resources
The subscription is in a different region

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Diagnostic settings.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Enable diagnostic settings (and any required flow log features) on the target resources to send logs/metrics to the workspace.

ul.li: Not all logs are enabled by default.
Destination choice (workspace vs storage vs event hub) affects queryability and cost.
Verify resource-specific log categories and prerequisites.

question.title: "I Need to See Who Changed This"
question.scenario: You must identify who modified an NSG rule yesterday.

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Activity Log.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use the Activity Log (subscription-level) to find the write operation for the NSG and identify the caller and timestamp.

ul.li: For longer retention and querying, export Activity Log to Log Analytics.
Data-plane logs won't show control-plane NSG changes.
Ensure the relevant subscription's Activity Log is checked (multi-subscription environments).

question.title: Resource Move: RG vs Subscription
question.scenario: You must move a set of resources to a new subscription for billing separation.
question.question-text: What are the two key prechecks?

choices.choice: Check if resources are running and stop them
Validate move support and ensure dependencies/permissions across scopes
Delete the resources and recreate them

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Validate move support and ensure dependencies/permissions across scopes.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Confirm the resource types support move across subscriptions, ensure all dependent resources can be moved together (or refactored), and ensure you have required permissions in both source and destination.

ul.li: Some resources have move constraints (resource provider-specific); verify official docs.
RBAC assignments and managed identities may need revalidation after move.
Policy differences in destination subscription can block resources post-move.

question.title: "Policy vs Lock" for Deletion Prevention
question.scenario: You need to prevent accidental deletion of a resource group, but admins still must be able to deploy within it.

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: CanNotDelete lock on the RG.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Apply a CanNotDelete lock at the resource group scope; it prevents deletion while allowing normal operations.

ul.li: Lock removal requires appropriate permissions; restrict who can remove it.
Locks can block IaC that replaces resources via delete/recreate.
Locks do not prevent destructive actions that don't require delete (e.g., misconfig changes).

question.title: Identity: Group-Based Access
question.scenario: You onboard 50 contractors for 3 months. They need Reader access to a subscription.

choices.choice: Assign Reader role to each contractor individually
Use an Entra ID group assigned to Reader role at subscription scope
Create guest accounts without any role assignment

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Use an Entra ID group assigned to Reader role at subscription scope.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Create an Entra ID group (e.g., Contractors-SubA-Readers) and assign Reader role at the subscription scope; add/remove users from the group as contractors change.

ul.li: Group-based assignments reduce churn and audit complexity.
Time-bound access can be handled via access reviews/PIM if used (verify exam expectations).
Ensure contractors don't get implicit access from other group memberships.

question.title: Storage "Delete Protection" Mix-Up
question.scenario: A team believes enabling blob soft delete meets a strict WORM compliance requirement.
question.question-text: Is that correct? What do you use instead?

choices.choice: Yes, soft delete is sufficient for WORM

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: No; use immutability for WORM.

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Soft delete enables recovery from deletes/overwrites but does not enforce WORM. For compliance WORM, configure immutable storage policies (time-based retention/legal hold).

ul.li: Soft delete retention is a window, not a compliance lock.
Immutability changes operational behavior (no delete until retention ends).
Verify legal hold vs time-based retention semantics for your compliance scenario.

question.title: VM Access: Just Enough Exposure
question.scenario: Security forbids direct public RDP/SSH to VMs. Admins still need remote access.

choices.choice: Assign public IPs to all VMs
Use Azure Bastion or a jump host pattern
Open NSG rules for RDP/SSH from any source
Use Azure DNS for VM access

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Use a jump/bastion pattern (Azure Bastion or private access).

hint.label: Complete Explanation
hint.content: Use Azure Bastion (or a jump host in a protected subnet) so VMs have no public RDP/SSH exposure while admins connect through a controlled entry point.

ul.li: Bastion changes the access path; NSG rules and subnet placement matter.
Audit and conditional access can be applied at the access gateway layer.
Verify Bastion SKU/features for required session types and scale.

question.title: End-to-End Scenario: Secure, Governed Landing Zone Slice
question.scenario: You're asked to onboard a new application into Azure with: (1) enforced tags, (2) no public endpoints for storage, (3) least-privilege admin, (4) centralized logging, (5) budget alerts.

choices.choice: Use default settings without any additional configuration
Management group policy + private endpoint + RBAC groups + Log Analytics + budgets
Single subscription with all resources in one resource group
Rely on Azure Advisor recommendations only

hint.label: Brief Hint
hint.content: Management group policy + private endpoint + RBAC groups + Log Analytics + budgets.

ul.li: Governance: Management group + policy initiative enforcing tags and region/SKU constraints.
Storage: Private Endpoint + private DNS; disable or restrict public network access.
Access: Entra groups with RBAC at RG scope (network RG vs app RG separation).
Monitoring: Diagnostic settings to centralized Log Analytics; alerts via action groups.
Cost: Budget thresholds + tag-based reporting.
Biggest traps: DNS for Private Endpoints, policy denials breaking deployments, workspace permissions separate from resource RBAC.
Ensure dependencies (shared VNet, shared workspace) don't force broad permissions.
Any numeric limits/retention defaults should be treated as "verify in official docs" unless you've confirmed for your tenant/exam version.

term.name: Azure RBAC
term.definition: Authorization system for Azure resource actions using roles assigned at scopes.
term.exam-note: Controls what actions identities can perform on Azure resources.

term.name: Management Group
term.definition: Hierarchy layer above subscriptions for consistent policy/RBAC inheritance.
term.exam-note: Use for organizing subscriptions and applying consistent controls.

term.name: Azure Policy
term.definition: Governance engine that audits/enforces resource configuration using policy definitions/initiatives.
term.exam-note: Use deny effect to block noncompliant deployments, audit to report only.

term.name: Network Security Group (NSG)
term.definition: Layer 3/4 ACL applied at subnet/NIC for traffic filtering.
term.exam-note: Priority ordering matters - first match wins.

term.name: Private Endpoint
term.definition: Private IP interface in a VNet that maps to a PaaS resource; enables private access path.
term.exam-note: Requires correct DNS configuration to function properly.

term.name: Managed Identity
term.definition: Azure-managed identity for workloads; avoids storing credentials.

term.name: Key Vault
term.definition: Service for secrets/keys/certificates; commonly used with managed identity.
term.exam-note: Network restrictions can block access; ensure private endpoint/DNS if locked down.

term.name: Log Analytics Workspace
term.definition: Central store for logs queried via KQL.
term.exam-note: Requires separate access permissions from resource RBAC.

term.name: Availability Zone
term.definition: Physically separate zone within a region; improves resilience against datacenter failures.
term.exam-note: Zone support is regional; verify per region.

term.name: VM Scale Set (VMSS)
term.definition: Managed fleet of identical VMs supporting autoscale and uniform updates.
term.exam-note: Best for stateless tiers; stateful workloads complicate scaling.
